awd_titl_txt: GP-Impact: Freshman Year to Geoscience Career
awd_abstract_narration:
The "Freshman Year To Geoscience Career" project addresses the important national goal of recruiting, retaining, and preparing the next generation workforce in the science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) disciplines, with specific focus on increasing diversity in the geosciences. Today, nearly 45% of all college students begin their undergraduate education at a community college; for underrepresented minority (URM) college students, the community college starting point is even larger (54%). These students are often underrepresented in the geosciences, underprepared academically, and burdened by unique obstacles due to socioeconomic status and family responsibilities. Few are aware of geoscience as a possible career.  If these students transfer successfully into a bachelor's degree program, they are often delayed in completion of their degrees because of inadequate math preparation and missing prerequisites, as well as the common necessity of working 20-40 hours/week to support themselves and their families. Many drop out of the pipeline, either because they are unable to complete the rigorous degree requirements or because they feel isolated and a sense of "not belonging."  Even if they complete their degrees, many of these students are first in their families to go to college and have little idea of how and when to plan for what follows graduation. To address these obstacles, this project is creating a seamless, supportive path from the time a student chooses a college major to when s/he enters graduate school or employment as a geoscientist. 

This multi-campus partnership between Queens College, a 4-year college in the City University of New York (CUNY) system, and LaGuardia and Queensborough Community Colleges guarantees help for students from unusually diverse ethnic and economic backgrounds, regardless of where they first enter the education pipeline. Innovative strategies in this effort address transitions at four key points at which students make or confirm the decision to pursue a career in Geology or Environmental Science, or to drop out of the STEM pipeline: 1) Starting a geoscience career path at a community college; 2) Transfer from a 2-year to 4-year college; 3) Completing a rigorous geoscience major; and 4) Transition to graduate school or geoscience employment. Through customized workshops and outreach at the community colleges, students are building the skills needed for a science career and being provided with information about career options and salaries in the geosciences.  Coordinated multi-campus recruiting and advising by peers and faculty from all three campuses are helping students make strategic coursework choices that better articulate with the degree requirements at the 4-year institution.  A unique geoscience learning community spanning all three campuses is helping to make the transition from 2-year to 4-year seamless. New majors have an opportunity to mingle with advanced students and faculty from the Queens College campuses before and throughout the academic year at academic (colloquia, field trips) and social events. By the time they transfer from their community college, students know the Queens faculty and the best path to degree completion. Modest stipends are being provided that make possible a geoscience service-learning culture for superior students, saving travel to and from off-campus jobs unrelated to their career goals. Stipend recipients serve as teaching aides and tutors in introductory courses, helping others understand basic concepts while deepening their own understanding. Some tutees will become the next generation of geoscience majors and tutors. Because calculus is known nationally as one of the major obstacles to completing a geoscience degree, free tutoring is being provided by Time 2000, a Queens College initiative that trains students to become high school math teachers. To better prepare students for their lives after graduation, the project is offering a series of workshops, starting in the freshman year, that help individuals choose job or graduate school; write resumes, personal statements, and application letters; and learn interview skills.

The principal intellectual merit of this project is to test two innovative models for improving student engagement, academic performance, and retention: 1) a unique discipline-specific learning community spanning three urban campuses - two Associates (community college) and one Bachelor's-Master's college, and 2) a service-learning approach to engaging students that removes or lessens the need of financially challenged geoscience majors to work off-campus at jobs unrelated to their professional goals.  Although the "Freshman Year to Geoscience Career" project is designed specifically to increase the number and diversity of geoscience students at the participating CUNY system campuses, the problems it addresses are endemic and the solutions it offers can serve as a model across all academic institutions and disciplines.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: “Freshman Year to Geoscience Career,” tested holistic approaches to recruiting and retaining diverse students for Geology and Environmental Science degrees in a multicampus urban university, where many students transition to a Baccalaureate campus after completing an Associates degree at a community college. Outcomes of three broad approaches to remove or lessen nationally recognized obstacles to degree completion include:

(1)   Create a nurturing multicampus Geoscience Community among two community colleges and a Baccalaureate/Masters college of the City University of New York. A sense of community developed among both students and faculty at the three campuses that allayed student fears of transitioning to a Baccalaureate campus. A collegiate aculty spirit developed early in project implementation, as Associates and Baccalaureate faculty gained an understanding each other’s needs, expectations, and issues facing their students. This was a two-way street, with colleagues from each campus participating in planning, recruiting, and intellectual activities at the others.

That understanding led to detailed articulation agreements; uniform gateway courses at the three campuses; improved, hands-on pedagogy; and joint research efforts that created a seamless transition from an Associates to a Bachelors degree.

The strategy for Associate degree students was to familiarize themwith the  Baccalaureate campus long before making the transition, through tours of facilities at which they met future faculty and peers; participation in weekly colloquia (in person at first, but later virtually because of COVID); and through common research areas shared among campuses. The research connection was expanded at symposia highlighting  work done by students at all three campuses. Symposium participants saw a broad spectrum of research topics, mingled with students and faculty from the other campuses, and, in several instances, connected with future mentors at the Baccalaureate campus.

 (2) Increase engagement through on- and off-campus service learning that offer real-world geoscience experiences as a prelude to employment or graduate school. This was also designed to show students  the relevance of their coursework and provide experiences in what geoscience careers entail. Service learning was largely off-campus at the community colleges, with participation in environmental maintenance and improvement projects sponsored by numerous NGOs. Service learning was largely internal at the Baccalaureate college. Students served other students as tutors in, at first, the Geology and Environmental Science gateway courses, and later in advanced courses as well.  In the last two years, collaboration with an HSI-STEM grant expanded service learning roles to those of peer mentors who participated in lecture and laboratory segments of the gateway courses, supported by training by Secondary Education science faculty with a strong Geoscience background.

 (3) Provide career counseling at all three campuses throughout a student’s tenure: Career advising begins at all three campuses the moment a student declares a Geoscience major. Students are thus aware of the wide variety of available occupations and graduate school programs as early as possible, and are advised throughout their undergraduate programs about  how best to achieve their career goals.

 Outcomes: Specific outcomes include:

♦  Geoscience Bachelors degree students are far more diverse than prior to GEOPATHS interventions (now approximately 65% of the total) and, for the first time, more than half are now women.

♦ The number of students continuing from the two Associates to the Baccalaureate college for a Bachelors degree has increased from a handful to more than 25 per year. Associate campus GEOPATHS coordinators also report that more of their students are now pursuing Bachelors degrees at other colleges as well.

♦ The number of Geology and Environmental Science majors has more than doubled during the GEOPATHS project to over 160, with another 75 in a more policy-oriented Environmental Studies program.

♦ Associate degree transfers complete their Bachelors degrees more rapidly than first-time freshmen at the Baccalaureate campus, and at the same level of academic performance.

♦ Several former Associate Degree students have now entered an accelerated Masters degree program or gone on to graduate studies.

♦ Tutoring and peer mentoring are described as extremely valuable experiences by students who plan to become secondary science teachers.

Broader Impacts: The problems that our GEOPATHS interventions address are endemic throughout academia, and our strategies to resolve them can be adopted nationally – and not just in the Geosciences.

♦ Our strategy for facilitating a seamless transition from a community college to a Baccalaureate campus is valuable at a time when such large numbers of students begin higher education at an Associates degree institution.

♦ Distance learning necessitated by the COVID-19 pandemic showed that even campuses separated by significant distances can pursue multi-campus community development.

♦ Strategies to increase student engagement through tutoring and peer mentoring help both the tutors and tutees transcend all disciplines and will succeed in humanities and social science as well as science.
